Review:
Mainstays in TorontoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s music scene since their inception in 2011, CAIRO have gone through a few different incarnations over the course of their young career. Whether changing band members or even band names, nearly four years of honing their orchestral alt-pop sound has at last resulted in a debut full-length record. On A History of Reasons, the five-piece have pulled off their ambitious genre-blending with aplomb, skilfully fusing rock, pop and folk across 11 tracks.
The result of this musical mixture makes for an enthralling listen, tastefully shaped by the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s attention to layering and dynamics. Nate DanielsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ vocals are at the forefront of each track, proving commanding from the wordless chant that begins the recordÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s title track. Harmonizing at times with his band mates, Daniels shows off his impressive range through soaring choruses, particularly on Ã¢â‚¬Å“With YouÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“Render.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½
Toeing a line between scintillating pop and subdued folk, the precise rhythm section and reverb-laced guitar work are only made richer by the inclusion of Caitlin GrieveÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s violin. Her playing functions well in instances of layered accompaniment and as a solo instrument, as demonstrated at the emotional pinnacle of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Starry Eyes.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ This compositional awareness allows the blending of genres across A History of Reasons to come together in a clean, coherent fashion without feeling forced Ã¢â‚¬â€ a strength that bodes well for the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s future.
